isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - SINGLE REDUCTION AXLES WITH CONTROLLED TRACTION DIFFERENTIALS: EATON - CTD SHIFT SYSTEM - TANDEM AXLE SHIFT SYSTEMS

svcsubproc.title: Description and Operation
svcsubproc.para: The CTD shift system provides the option of operation with the Controlled Traction Differential engaged or disengaged with the use of an in-cab pneumatic valve.
Two shift units (one on each axle) engage or disengage the Controlled Traction Differentials. A quick release valve in the system provides fast release of air pressure from the shift units.

There are two types of CTD shift systems for tandem axles ( Figure 43): (1) a one-selector valve system controlling operation of the inter-axle differential and both controlled traction differentials, or (2) a two-selector valve system which offers independent control of the inter-axle differential and the controlled traction differentials.

figure.caption: Figure 43. CTD Shift Systems - Tandem Axles

svcsubproc.para: Instructions in this manual are the same for both systems unless specified otherwise.

Engagement. When the selector valve lever is moved to the engaged position, the selector valve is opened and air pressure is applied to the shift unit (or units). Each shift unit is connected to a shift fork and sliding clutch. The sliding clutch moves to engage the controlled traction differential. In the engaged position, the wheel differential acts as a biasing differential.
In the one-selector valve system, the CTD and inter-axle differential are controlled by one valve and both are engaged when the selector valve is in the engaged position.
In the two-selector valve system, both CTD differentials and the inter-axle differential are engaged independently.

Disengagement. When the selector valve lever is moved to the disengaged position, the selector valve is closed. Air pressure in the shift unit (or units) is exhausted. The sliding clutch retracts and disengages the controlled traction differential. In the disengaged position, the wheel differential functions with conventional differential action.
In the one-selector valve system, both CTD differentials and inter-axle differential are disengaged when the selector valve is in the disengaged position.
In the two-selector valve system, both CTD differentials and the inter-axle differential are disengaged independently.
CTD Shift Unit. For detailed description and operation, refer to CTS-5166 in GROUP 14 - REAR AXLES of the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
Inter-Axle Differential Lockout Shift Unit. For detailed description and operation, refer to the appropriate Eaton Axle Service Manual covering your axle model.
Except where specified otherwise, the following instructions cover Controlled Traction Shift Systems with one or two selector valves.

important.para: Before starting a system check, make sure the inter-axle differential is disengaged. Also, operate engine until full system air pressure (reservoir pressure) is built up in the system.

svcsubproc.title: Disengage Inter-Axle Differential (One-Selector Valve System)
svcsubproc.para: For vehicles equipped with a system that engages both CTD differentials when the inter-axle differential is engaged, the following steps must be taken to make sure the inter-axle differential is disengaged before checking the CTD shift system.

step1.para: Start system check by releasing the parking brake and place transmission in neutral.
Place the inter-axle differential selector valve in the disengaged position.
Lift both wheels of rear axle off the ground.

Rotate the inter-axle drive shaft. If drive shaft turns, the inter-axle differential is disengaged. If it does not turn, the inter-axle differential shift mechanism is not functioning properly. Refer to appropriate Eaton Axle Service Manual for disassembly and repair.
After confirming that the inter-axle differential is disengaged, disconnect the air line connected to the inter-axle differential lockout shift unit and plug the end of the line.

warning.para: High pressure may be present when disconnecting air line. Exert caution to prevent possible personal injury.

step1.para: Disengage Inter-Axle Differential (Two Selector Valve System) For vehicles equipped with two selector valves, one for operating the inter-axle differential shift unit and the other for the CTD shift units, the following steps must be taken to make sure the inter-axle differential is disengaged.
Release the parking brake and place the vehicle transmission in neutral.
Place the inter-axle differential selector valve in the disengaged position.
Lift both wheels of the rear axle off the ground.

Rotate the inter-axle drive shaft. If the shaft turns, the inter-axle differential is disengaged. If it does not turn, the inter-axle differential shift mechanism is not functioning properly. Refer to the appropriate Eaton Axle Service Manual for disassembly and repair.

svcsubproc.title: Check Controlled Traction Differential Shift System

step1.para: Two-Valve System. Start the System check by placing the CTD selector valve in the disengaged position (inter-axle differential selector valve should still be in the disengaged position).
One-Valve System. Make sure the inter-axle differential selector valve is still in the disengaged position.

svcsubproc.para: Both Systems. Make sure the parking brake is released and the transmission is in neutral.

step1.para: Lift the wheel on the shift unit side of rear axle off the ground. Turn the wheel. Both the wheel and the inter-axle drive shaft should rotate. If the wheel rotates, go to Step 6. If wheel will not rotate, proceed to the next step.

warning.para: High pressure may be present when disconnecting air line. Exert caution to prevent possible personal injury

A jack must never be used alone to support vehicle while under-chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with floor stands.

step1.para: Verify that there is no air pressure at the rear axle shift unit by removing the air line. If air pressure is present, check for blockage of exhaust port at selector valve. If none is found, the CTD selector valve (or inter-axle differential selector valve) is defective and needs replacement.

If no air pressure is present at the shift unit, remove the shift unit and have an assistant move the CTD selector valve back and forth. The shift unit linkage should move accordingly. If the linkage does not move, disassemble shift unit and repair. Refer to CTS-5166 in GROUP 14 - REAR AXLES of the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual. If the shift unit functions properly, proceed to Step 5.

With the shift unit removed, move the protruding end of the shift fork from side to side. If the shift fork will not move, the problem is in the differential carrier assembly. Remove carrier and inspect components.
Two-Valve System. Move the CTD selector valve to the engaged position.
One-Valve System. Move inter-axle differential selector valve to the engaged position.

svcsubproc.para: Both Systems. Turn the wheel that is off the ground. Neither wheel or the inter-axle drive shaft should rotate.

step1.para: If the wheel rotates, check to make sure that there is full system air pressure at the rear axle shift unit by removing the air line. If no air pressure is present, the CTD selector valve (or inter-axle differential selector valve) is defective and needs replacement.

If air pressure is present at the shift unit, remove the unit by first placing the CTD selector valve in the disengaged position. Once the shift unit is removed, have an assistant move the CTD selector valve back and forth. The shift unit linkage should move accordingly. If the linkage does not move, disassemble the shift unit and repair. Refer to CTS-5166 in GROUP 14 - REAR AXLES of the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual. If the shift unit functions properly, move the protruding end of the shift fork from side to side. If the shift fork will not move, remove differential carrier and check components.
Use same procedure to troubleshoot forward axle controlled traction differential.
